verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:397
verses.text: Hesychius replied that he was the agent at the country-house to which the garden belonged in which they were located.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:398
verses.text: Weeping much and stretching out his hand to the prostrate man he said, "I bid you in the name of our Lord Jesus Christ arise and walk".

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:399
verses.text: The words were still on the lips of the speaker, when, with miraculous speed, the limbs were strengthened and the man arose and stood firm.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:400
verses.text: Once this was noised abroad the need of many overcame even the pathless journey and the dangers of the place.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:401
verses.text: The occupants of all the houses round about had nothing so much in their thoughts as to prevent the possibility of his escape, a rumour having spread concerning him to the effect that he could not stay long in the same place.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:402
verses.text: This habit of his was not due to levity or childishness, but to the fact that he shunned the worry of publicity and praise, and always longed for silence and a life of obscurity.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:404
verses.text: In his eightieth year, during the absence of Hesychius, he wrote by way of a will a short letter with his own hand, and left him all his riches (that is to say, a copy of the gospels, and his sack-cloth tunic, cowl and cloak), for his servant had died a few days before.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:405
verses.text: Many devout men therefore came to the invalid from Paphos, and specially because they had heard of his saying that he must soon migrate to the Lord and must be liberated from the bonds of the body.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:406
verses.text: There came also Constantia a holy woman whose son-in-law and daughter he had anointed with oil and saved from death.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:407
verses.text: He earnestly entreated them all not to let him be kept even a moment of time after death, but to bury him immediately in the same garden, just as he was, clad in his goat-hair tunic, cowl, and his peasant's cloak.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:409
verses.text: His body was now all but cold, and nought was left of life but reason.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:410
verses.text: Yet with eyes wide open he kept repeating, "Go forth, what do you fear? Go forth, my soul, why do you hesitate? You have served Christ nearly seventy years, and do you fear death?" Thus saying he breathed his last.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:411
verses.text: He was immediately buried before the city heard of his death.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:413
verses.text: When the holy man Hesychius heard of his decease, he went to Cyprus and, to lull the suspicions of the natives who were keeping strict guard, pretended that he wished to live in the same garden, and then in the course of about ten months, though at great peril to his life, stole the saint's body.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:414
verses.text: He carried it to Majuma; and there all the monks and crowds of towns-folk going in procession laid it to rest in the ancient monastery.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:415
verses.text: His tunic, cowl and cloak, were uninjured; the whole body as perfect as if alive, and so fragrant with sweet odours that one might suppose it to have been embalmed.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:417
verses.text: In bringing my book to an end I think I ought not to omit to mention the devotion of the holy woman Constantia who, when a message was brought her that Hilarion's body was in Palestine, immediately died, proving even by death the sincerity of her love for the servant of God.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:418
verses.text: For she was accustomed to spend whole nights in vigil at his tomb, and to converse with him as if he were present in order to stimulate her prayers.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:419
verses.text: Even at the present day one may see a strange dispute between the people of Palestine and the Cypriotes, the one contending that they have the body, the other the spirit of Hilarion.

verses.name: Jerome: The Life of Hilarion 1:420
verses.text: And yet in both places great miracles are wrought daily, but to a greater extent in the garden of Cyprus, perhaps because that spot was dearest to him.
